194 /**
195  Status when storing a value in a field or converting from one
196  datatype to another. The values should be listed in order of
197  increasing seriousness so that if two type_conversion_status
198  variables are compared, the bigger one is most serious.
199 */
200 enum type_conversion_status {
201  /// Storage/conversion went fine.
202  TYPE_OK = 0,
203  /**
204  A minor problem when converting between temporal values, e.g.
205  if datetime is converted to date the time information is lost.
206  */
207  TYPE_NOTE_TIME_TRUNCATED,
208  /**
209  Value was stored, but something was cut. What was cut is
210  considered insignificant enough to only issue a note. Example:
211  trying to store a number with 5 decimal places into a field that
212  can only store 3 decimals. The number rounded to 3 decimal places
213  should be stored. Another example: storing the string "foo " into
214  a VARCHAR(3). The string "foo" is stored in this case, so only
215  whitespace is cut.
216  */
217  TYPE_NOTE_TRUNCATED,
218  /**
219  Value outside min/max limit of datatype. The min/max value is
220  stored by Field::store() instead (if applicable)
221  */
222  TYPE_WARN_OUT_OF_RANGE,
223  /**
224  Value was stored, but something was cut. What was cut is
225  considered significant enough to issue a warning. Example: storing
226  the string "foo" into a VARCHAR(2). The string "fo" is stored in
227  this case. Another example: storing the string "2010-01-01foo"
228  into a DATE. The garbage in the end of the string is cut in this
229  case.
230  */
231  TYPE_WARN_TRUNCATED,
232  /**
233  Value has invalid string data. When present in a predicate with
234  equality operator, range optimizer returns an impossible where.
235  */
236  TYPE_WARN_INVALID_STRING,
237  /// Trying to store NULL in a NOT NULL field.
238  TYPE_ERR_NULL_CONSTRAINT_VIOLATION,
239  /**
240  Store/convert incompatible values, like converting "foo" to a
241  date.
242  */
243  TYPE_ERR_BAD_VALUE,
244  /// Out of memory
245  TYPE_ERR_OOM
246 };

260 inline uint get_enum_pack_length(int elements) {
261  return elements < 256 ? 1 : 2;
262 }
263 
264 inline uint get_set_pack_length(int elements) {
265  uint len = (elements + 7) / 8;
266  return len > 4 ? 8 : len;
267 }

269 inline type_conversion_status decimal_err_to_type_conv_status(int dec_error) {
270  if (dec_error & E_DEC_OOM) return TYPE_ERR_OOM;
271 
272  if (dec_error & (E_DEC_DIV_ZERO | E_DEC_BAD_NUM)) return TYPE_ERR_BAD_VALUE;
273 
274  if (dec_error & E_DEC_TRUNCATED) return TYPE_NOTE_TRUNCATED;
275 
276  if (dec_error & E_DEC_OVERFLOW) return TYPE_WARN_OUT_OF_RANGE;
277 
278  if (dec_error == E_DEC_OK) return TYPE_OK;
279 
280  // impossible
281  DBUG_ASSERT(false);
282  return TYPE_ERR_BAD_VALUE;
283 }
284 
285 /**
286  Convert warnings returned from str_to_time() and str_to_datetime()
287  to their corresponding type_conversion_status codes.
288 */
289 inline type_conversion_status time_warning_to_type_conversion_status(
290  const int warn) {
291  if (warn & MYSQL_TIME_NOTE_TRUNCATED) return TYPE_NOTE_TIME_TRUNCATED;
292 
293  if (warn & MYSQL_TIME_WARN_OUT_OF_RANGE) return TYPE_WARN_OUT_OF_RANGE;
294 
295  if (warn & MYSQL_TIME_WARN_TRUNCATED) return TYPE_NOTE_TRUNCATED;
296 
297  if (warn & (MYSQL_TIME_WARN_ZERO_DATE | MYSQL_TIME_WARN_ZERO_IN_DATE))
298  return TYPE_ERR_BAD_VALUE;
299 
300  if (warn & MYSQL_TIME_WARN_INVALID_TIMESTAMP)
301  // date was fine but pointed to daylight saving time switch gap
302  return TYPE_OK;
303 
304  DBUG_ASSERT(!warn);
305  return TYPE_OK;
306 }

315 /**
316  Tests if field type is an integer
317 
318  @param type Field type, as returned by field->type()
319 
320  @returns true if integer type, false otherwise
321 */
322 inline bool is_integer_type(enum_field_types type) {
323  switch (type) {
324  case MYSQL_TYPE_TINY:
325  case MYSQL_TYPE_SHORT:
326  case MYSQL_TYPE_INT24:
327  case MYSQL_TYPE_LONG:
328  case MYSQL_TYPE_LONGLONG:
329  case MYSQL_TYPE_YEAR:
330  return true;
331  default:
332  return false;
333  }
334 }

351  case MYSQL_TYPE_FLOAT:
352  case MYSQL_TYPE_DOUBLE:

391  @retval true If field type is temporal
392  @retval false If field type is not temporal

408  Tests if field real type is temporal, i.e. represents
409  all existing implementations of
410  DATE, TIME, DATETIME or TIMESTAMP types in SQL.
411 
412  @param type Field real type, as returned by field->real_type()
413  @retval true If field real type is temporal
414  @retval false If field real type is not temporal

418  case MYSQL_TYPE_TIME2:
419  case MYSQL_TYPE_TIMESTAMP2:
420  case MYSQL_TYPE_DATETIME2:
421  return true;
422  default:
423  return is_temporal_type(type);
424  }

517 /**
518  Convert temporal real types as retuned by field->real_type()
519  to field type as returned by field->type().
520 
521  @param real_type Real type.
522  @retval Field type.
523 */
524 inline enum_field_types real_type_to_type(enum_field_types real_type) {
525  switch (real_type) {
526  case MYSQL_TYPE_TIME2:
527  return MYSQL_TYPE_TIME;
528  case MYSQL_TYPE_DATETIME2:
529  return MYSQL_TYPE_DATETIME;
530  case MYSQL_TYPE_TIMESTAMP2:
531  return MYSQL_TYPE_TIMESTAMP;
532  case MYSQL_TYPE_NEWDATE:
533  return MYSQL_TYPE_DATE;
534  /* Note: NEWDECIMAL is a type, not only a real_type */
535  default:
536  return real_type;
537  }
538 }

540 /**
541  Return the appropriate MYSQL_TYPE_X_BLOB value based on the
542  pack_length.
543 
544  @param pack_length pack_length for BLOB
545  @retval MYSQL_TYPE_X_BLOB corresponding to pack_length.
546 */
547 inline enum_field_types blob_type_from_pack_length(uint pack_length) {
548  DBUG_TRACE;
549  switch (pack_length) {
550  case 1:
551  return MYSQL_TYPE_TINY_BLOB;
552  case 2:
553  return MYSQL_TYPE_BLOB;
554  case 3:
555  return MYSQL_TYPE_MEDIUM_BLOB;
556  case 4:
557  return MYSQL_TYPE_LONG_BLOB;
558  default:
559  DBUG_ASSERT(false);
560  return MYSQL_TYPE_LONG_BLOB;
561  }
562 }

564 /**
565  Copies an integer value to a format comparable with memcmp(). The
566  format is characterized by the following:
567 
568  - The sign bit goes first and is unset for negative values.
569  - The representation is big endian.
570 
571  The function template can be instantiated to copy from little or
572  big endian values.
573 
574  @tparam Is_big_endian True if the source integer is big endian.
575 
576  @param to Where to write the integer.
577  @param to_length Size in bytes of the destination buffer.
578  @param from Where to read the integer.
579  @param from_length Size in bytes of the source integer
580  @param is_unsigned True if the source integer is an unsigned value.
581 */
582 template <bool Is_big_endian>
583 void copy_integer(uchar *to, size_t to_length, const uchar *from,
584  size_t from_length, bool is_unsigned) {
585  if (to_length == 0) return;
586  if (Is_big_endian) {
587  std::copy(from, from + std::min(to_length, from_length), to);
588  if (!is_unsigned)
589  to[0] = static_cast<char>(to[0] ^ 128); // Reverse the sign bit.
590  } else {
591  const uchar *from_end = from + from_length;
592  const uchar *from_start = from_end - std::min(from_length, to_length);
593  std::reverse_copy(from_start, from_end, to);
594  if (!is_unsigned)
595  to[0] = static_cast<char>(to[0] ^ 128); // Reverse the sign bit.
596  }
597 }

599 /**
600  Enum to indicate source for which value generator is used. This is needed
601  while unpacking value generator expression and pre-validating the
602  expression for generated column, default expression or check constraint.
603 */
604 enum Value_generator_source : short {
605  VGS_GENERATED_COLUMN = 0, // Value generator for GENERATED_COLUMN.
606  VGS_DEFAULT_EXPRESSION, // Value generator for Default expression.
607  VGS_CHECK_CONSTRAINT // Value generator for check constraints.
608 };

610 /**
611  Used for storing information associated with generated column, default
612  values generated from expression or check constraint expression.
613 */
614 class Value_generator {
615  public:
616  /**
617  Item representing the generation expression.
618  This is non-NULL for every Field of a TABLE, if that field is a generated
619  column.
620  Contrast this with the Field of a TABLE_SHARE, which has expr_item==NULL
621  even if it's a generated column; that makes sense, as an Item tree cannot
622  be shared.
623  */
624  Item *expr_item;
625  /**
626  Text of the expression. Used in only one case:
627  - the text read from the DD is put into the Value_generator::expr_str of
628  the Field of the TABLE_SHARE; then this expr_str is used as source
629  to produce expr_item for the Field of every TABLE derived from this
630  TABLE_SHARE.
631  */
632  LEX_STRING expr_str;
633 
634  /**
635  Bit field indicating the type of statement for binary logging.
636  It needs to be saved because this is determined only once when it is parsed
637  but it needs to be set on the lex for each statement that uses this
638  value generator. And since unpacking is done once on table open, it will
639  be set for the rest of the statements in refix_inner_value_generator_items.
640  */
641  uint32 m_backup_binlog_stmt_flags{0};
642 
643  /// List of all items created when parsing and resolving generated expression
644  Item *item_list;
645  /// Bitmap records base columns which a generated column depends on.
646  MY_BITMAP base_columns_map;
647 
648  Value_generator()
649  : expr_item(nullptr),
650  item_list(nullptr),
651  field_type(MYSQL_TYPE_LONG),
652  stored_in_db(false),
653  num_non_virtual_base_cols(0),
654  permanent_changes_completed(false) {
655  expr_str.str = nullptr;
656  expr_str.length = 0;
657  }
658  ~Value_generator() {}
659  enum_field_types get_real_type() const { return field_type; }
660 
661  void set_field_type(enum_field_types fld_type) { field_type = fld_type; }
662 
663  /**
664  Set the binary log flags in m_backup_binlog_stmt_flags
665  @param backup_binlog_stmt_flags the falgs to be backed up
666  */
667  void backup_stmt_unsafe_flags(uint32 backup_binlog_stmt_flags) {
668  m_backup_binlog_stmt_flags = backup_binlog_stmt_flags;
669  }
670 
671  /**
672  Get the binary log flags from m_backup_binlog_stmt_flags
673  @return the flags backed up by unpack_value_generator
674  */
675  uint32 get_stmt_unsafe_flags() { return m_backup_binlog_stmt_flags; }
676 
677  bool get_field_stored() const { return stored_in_db; }
678  void set_field_stored(bool stored) { stored_in_db = stored; }
679  bool register_base_columns(TABLE *table);
680  /**
681  Get the number of non virtual base columns that this generated
682  column needs.
683 
684  @return number of non virtual base columns
685  */

723 class Field {
724  public:
725  /*
726  Field(const Item &) = delete;
727  The original intention was seemingly for Field to be non-copyable,
728  but due to a typo, this was never enforced, and now there's lots of
729  code that copies Field objects around. Thus, the default copy
730  constructor needs to stay (assignment is blocked off), but it's probably
731  better not to write code that depends on it.
732  */

1118  /*
1119  val_str(buf1, buf2) gets two buffers and should use them as follows:
1120  if it needs a temp buffer to convert result to string - use buf1
1121  example Field_tiny::val_str()
1122  if the value exists as a string already - use buf2
1123  example Field_string::val_str()
1124  consequently, buf2 may be created as 'String buf;' - no memory
1125  will be allocated for it. buf1 will be allocated to hold a
1126  value if it's too small. Using allocated buffer for buf2 may result in
1127  an unnecessary free (and later, may be an alloc).
1128  This trickery is used to decrease a number of malloc calls.
1129  */

1209  /**
1210  Returns a UTC component in `struct timeval` format. This interface
1211  makes any column appear to be `TIMESTAMP`, i.e. stored in UTC, and
1212  returns the UTC component in (optionally fractional) seconds. This means
1213  converting _to_ UTC from the current session's time zone for types other
1214  than `TIMESTAMP`.
1215 
1216  This method was expressly written for `SELECT UNIX_TIMESTAMP(field)`
1217  to avoid conversion from timestamp to MYSQL_TIME and back.
1218  */
1219  virtual bool get_timestamp(struct timeval *tm, int *warnings) const;
1220  /**
1221  Stores a timestamp value in timeval format in a field.
1222 
1223  @note
1224  - store_timestamp(), get_timestamp() and store_time() do not depend on
1225  timezone and always work "in UTC".
1226 
1227  - The default implementation of this interface expects that storing the
1228  value will not fail. For most Field descendent classes, this is not the
1229  case. However, this interface is only used when the function
1230  CURRENT_TIMESTAMP is used as a column default expression, and currently we
1231  only allow TIMESTAMP and DATETIME columns to be declared with this as the
1232  column default. Hence it is enough that the classes implementing columns
1233  with these types either override this interface, or that
1234  store_time(MYSQL_TIME*, uint8) does not fail.
1235 
1236  - The column types above interpret decimals() to mean the scale of the
1237  fractional seconds.
1238 
1239  - We also have the limitation that the scale of a column must be the same as
1240  the scale of the CURRENT_TIMESTAMP. I.e. we only allow
1241 
1242  @code
1243 
1244  [ TIMESTAMP | DATETIME ] (n) [ DEFAULT | ON UPDATE ] CURRENT_TIMESTAMP (n)
1245 
1246  @endcode
1247 
1248  Since this interface relies on the caller to truncate the value according to
1249  this Field's scale, it will work with all constructs that we currently allow.
1250  */
1251  virtual void store_timestamp(const timeval *) { DBUG_ASSERT(false); }

1255  /**
1256  Evaluates the @c INSERT default function and stores the result in the
1257  field. If no such function exists for the column, or the function is not
1258  valid for the column's data type, invoking this function has no effect.
1259  */
1260  void evaluate_insert_default_function();
1261 
1262  /**
1263  Evaluates the @c UPDATE default function, if one exists, and stores the
1264  result in the record buffer. If no such function exists for the column,
1265  or the function is not valid for the column's data type, invoking this
1266  function has no effect.
1267  */
1268  void evaluate_update_default_function();
1269  virtual bool binary() const { return true; }
1270  virtual bool zero_pack() const { return true; }
1271  virtual enum ha_base_keytype key_type() const { return HA_KEYTYPE_BINARY; }
1272  virtual uint32 key_length() const { return pack_length(); }
1273  virtual enum_field_types type() const = 0;
1274  virtual enum_field_types real_type() const { return type(); }
1275  virtual enum_field_types binlog_type() const {
1276  /*
1277  Binlog stores field->type() as type code by default.
1278  This puts MYSQL_TYPE_STRING in case of CHAR, VARCHAR, SET and ENUM,
1279  with extra data type details put into metadata.
1280 
1281  We cannot store field->type() in case of temporal types with
1282  fractional seconds: TIME(n), DATETIME(n) and TIMESTAMP(n),
1283  because binlog records with MYSQL_TYPE_TIME, MYSQL_TYPE_DATETIME
1284  type codes do not have metadata.
1285  So for temporal data types with fractional seconds we'll store
1286  real_type() type codes instead, i.e.
1287  MYSQL_TYPE_TIME2, MYSQL_TYPE_DATETIME2, MYSQL_TYPE_TIMESTAMP2,
1288  and put precision into metatada.
1289 
1290  Note: perhaps binlog should eventually be modified to store
1291  real_type() instead of type() for all column types.
1292  */
1293  return type();
1294  }

1297  uint max_len MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) const {
1298  return cmp(a, b);
1299  }
1300  virtual int cmp(const uchar *, const uchar *) const = 0;
1301  virtual int cmp_binary(const uchar *a, const uchar *b,
1302  uint32 max_length MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)) = ~0L) const {
1303  return memcmp(a, b, pack_length());
1304  }
1305  virtual int cmp_offset(ptrdiff_t row_offset) const {
1306  return cmp(ptr, ptr + row_offset);
1307  }

1309  return cmp_binary(ptr, ptr + row_offset);
1310  }

1328  /**
1329  Check whether the full table's row is NULL or the Field has value NULL.
1330 
1331  @return true if the full table's row is NULL or the Field has value NULL
1332  false if neither table's row nor the Field has value NULL
1333  */
1334  bool is_null(ptrdiff_t row_offset = 0) const {
1335  /*
1336  if the field is NULLable, it returns NULLity based
1337  on m_null_ptr[row_offset] value. Otherwise it returns
1338  NULL flag depending on TABLE::has_null_row() value.
1339 
1340  The table may have been marked as containing only NULL values
1341  for all fields if it is a NULL-complemented row of an OUTER JOIN
1342  or if the query is an implicitly grouped query (has aggregate
1343  functions but no GROUP BY clause) with no qualifying rows. If
1344  this is the case (in which TABLE::has_null_row() is true) and the
1345  field is not nullable, the field is considered to be NULL.
1346 
1347  Do not change the order of testing. Fields may be associated
1348  with a TABLE object without being part of the current row.
1349  For NULL value check to work for these fields, they must
1350  have a valid m_null_ptr, and this pointer must be checked before
1351  TABLE::has_null_row().
1352  */
1353  if (is_nullable()) return (m_null_ptr[row_offset] & null_bit);
1354 
1355  if (is_tmp_nullable()) return m_is_tmp_null;
1356 
1357  return table->has_null_row();
1358  }
1359 
1360  /**
1361  Check whether the Field has value NULL (temporary or actual).
1362 
1363  @return true if the Field has value NULL (temporary or actual)
1364  false if the Field has value NOT NULL.
1365  */
1366  bool is_real_null(ptrdiff_t row_offset = 0) const {
1367  if (is_nullable()) return (m_null_ptr[row_offset] & null_bit);
1368 
1369  if (is_tmp_nullable()) return m_is_tmp_null;
1370 
1371  return false;
1372  }
1373 
1374  /**
1375  Check if the Field has value NULL or the record specified by argument
1376  has value NULL for this Field.
1377 
1378  @return true if the Field has value NULL or the record has value NULL
1379  for thois Field.
1380  */
1381  bool is_null_in_record(const uchar *record) const {
1382  if (is_nullable()) return (record[null_offset()] & null_bit);
1383 
1384  return is_tmp_nullable() ? m_is_tmp_null : false;
1385  }

1505  /*
1506  Copy a field part into an output buffer.
1507 
1508  SYNOPSIS
1509  Field::get_key_image()
1510  buff [out] output buffer
1511  length output buffer size
1512  type itMBR for geometry blobs, otherwise itRAW
1513 
1514  DESCRIPTION
1515  This function makes a copy of field part of size equal to or
1516  less than "length" parameter value.
1517  For fields of string types (CHAR, VARCHAR, TEXT) the rest of buffer
1518  is padded by zero byte.
1519 
1520  NOTES
1521  For variable length character fields (i.e. UTF-8) the "length"
1522  parameter means a number of output buffer bytes as if all field
1523  characters have maximal possible size (mbmaxlen). In the other words,
1524  "length" parameter is a number of characters multiplied by
1525  field_charset->mbmaxlen.
1526 
1527  RETURN
1528  Number of copied bytes (excluding padded zero bytes -- see above).
1529  */
1530 
1531  virtual size_t get_key_image(uchar *buff, size_t length,
1532  imagetype type MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) const {
1533  get_image(buff, length, &my_charset_bin);
1534  return length;
1535  }
1536  virtual void set_key_image(const uchar *buff, size_t length) {
1537  set_image(buff, length, &my_charset_bin);
1538  }
1539  longlong val_int_offset(ptrdiff_t row_offset) {
1540  ptr += row_offset;
1541  longlong tmp = val_int();
1542  ptr -= row_offset;
1543  return tmp;
1544  }
1545  longlong val_int(uchar *new_ptr) {
1546  uchar *old_ptr = ptr;
1547  longlong return_value;
1548  ptr = new_ptr;
1549  return_value = val_int();
1550  ptr = old_ptr;
1551  return return_value;
1552  }
1553  String *val_str(String *str, uchar *new_ptr) {
1554  uchar *old_ptr = ptr;
1555  ptr = new_ptr;
1556  val_str(str);
1557  ptr = old_ptr;
1558  return str;
1559  }

1567  /**
1568  Pack the field into a format suitable for storage and transfer.
1569 
1570  To implement packing functionality, only the virtual function
1571  should be overridden. The other functions are just convenience
1572  functions and hence should not be overridden.
1573 
1574  The actual format is opaque and will vary between types of Field
1575  (it is meant to be unpacked by unpack(), but be aware that it is
1576  used among others in the replication log, so you cannot change it
1577  without incurring a format break.
1578 
1579  @note The default implementation just copies the raw bytes
1580  of the record into the destination, but never more than
1581  <code>max_length</code> characters.
1582 
1583  @param to
1584  Pointer to memory area where representation of field should be put.
1585 
1586  @param from
1587  Pointer to memory area where record representation of field is
1588  stored, typically field->field_ptr().
1589 
1590  @param max_length
1591  Available space in to, in bytes. pack() will not write more bytes than
1592  this; if the field is too short, the contents _are not unpackable by
1593  unpack()_. (It is nominally supposed to be a prefix of what would have
1594  been written with a full buffer, ie., the same as packing and then
1595  truncating the output, but not all Field classes follow this.)
1596 
1597  @return The byte after the last byte in to written to. If the return
1598  value is equal to (to + max_length), it could either be that the value
1599  fit exactly, or that the buffer was too small; you cannot distinguish
1600  between the two cases based on the return value alone.
1601  */
1602  virtual uchar *pack(uchar *to, const uchar *from, size_t max_length) const;
1603 
1604  uchar *pack(uchar *to) const { return pack(to, ptr, UINT_MAX); }
1605 
1606  virtual const uchar *unpack(uchar *to, const uchar *from, uint param_data);
1607 
1608  const uchar *unpack(const uchar *from) { return unpack(ptr, from, 0U); }
1609 
1610  /**
1611  This function does the same thing as pack(), except for the difference
1612  that max_length does not mean the number of bytes in the output, but the
1613  maximum field length from the input (which must be exactly
1614  field->max_field_length()). The difference is currently only relevant for
1615  Field_blob, but can be summed up as follows:
1616 
1617  - If the actual field length is longer than "max_length", by way of
1618  software bug or otherwise, the function may behave as if it were shorter,
1619  and write something that is still readable by unpack().
1620  - There is no bounds checking; the caller must verify that there is
1621  sufficient space in "to". Even in the case of truncation, "to" must
1622  be long enough to hold the untruncated field, as the return pointer
1623  would otherwise be invalid, causing undefined behavior as per the C++
1624  standard.
1625  */
1626  virtual uchar *pack_with_metadata_bytes(uchar *to, const uchar *from,
1627  uint max_length) const {
1628  return pack(to, from, max_length);
1629  }
1630 
1631  /**
1632  Write the field for the binary log in diff format.
1633 
1634  This should only write the field if the diff format is smaller
1635  than the full format. Otherwise it should leave the buffer
1636  untouched.
1637 
1638  @param[in,out] to Pointer to buffer where the field will be
1639  written. This will be changed to point to the next byte after the
1640  last byte that was written.
1641 
1642  @param value_options bitmap that indicates if full or partial
1643  JSON format is to be used.
1644 
1645  @retval true The field was not written, either because the data
1646  type does not support it, or because it was disabled according to
1647  value_options, or because there was no diff information available
1648  from the optimizer, or because the the diff format was bigger than
1649  the full format. The 'to' parameter is unchanged in this case.
1650 
1651  @retval false The field was written.
1652  */
1653  virtual bool pack_diff(uchar **to MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
1654  ulonglong value_options MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) const {
1655  return true;
1656  }

1939  uchar *pack_int24(uchar *to, const uchar *from, size_t max_length) const;
1940 
1941  const uchar *unpack_int24(uchar *to, const uchar *from) const;
1942 
1943  uchar *pack_int32(uchar *to, const uchar *from, size_t max_length) const;
1944 
1945  const uchar *unpack_int32(uchar *to, const uchar *from) const;
1946 
1947  uchar *pack_int64(uchar *to, const uchar *from, size_t max_length) const;

1949  const uchar *unpack_int64(uchar *to, const uchar *from) const;

1951 
1952 /**
1953  This class is a substitute for the Field classes during CREATE TABLE
1954 
1955  When adding a functional index at table creation, we need to resolve the
1956  expression we are indexing. All functions that references one or more
1957  columns expects a Field to be available. But during CREATE TABLE, we only
1958  have access to Create_field. So this class acts as a subsitute for the
1959  Field classes so that expressions can be properly resolved. Thus, trying
1960  to call store or val_* on this class will cause an assertion.
1961 */
1962 class Create_field_wrapper final : public Field {
1963  const Create_field *m_field;
1964 
1965  public:
1966  Create_field_wrapper(const Create_field *fld);
1967  Item_result result_type() const final;
1968  Item_result numeric_context_result_type() const final;
1969  enum_field_types type() const final;
1970  uint32 max_display_length() const final;
1971 
1972  const CHARSET_INFO *charset() const final;
1973 
1974  uint32 pack_length() const final;
1975 
1976  // Since it's not a real field, functions below shouldn't be used.
1977  /* purecov: begin deadcode */
1978  type_conversion_status store(const char *, size_t,
1979  const CHARSET_INFO *) final {
1980  DBUG_ASSERT(false);
1981  return TYPE_ERR_BAD_VALUE;
1982  }
1983  type_conversion_status store(double) final {
1984  DBUG_ASSERT(false);
1985  return TYPE_ERR_BAD_VALUE;
1986  }
1987  type_conversion_status store(longlong, bool) final {
1988  DBUG_ASSERT(false);
1989  return TYPE_ERR_BAD_VALUE;
1990  }
1991  type_conversion_status store_decimal(const my_decimal *) final {
1992  DBUG_ASSERT(false);
1993  return TYPE_ERR_BAD_VALUE;
1994  }
1995  double val_real(void) const final {
1996  DBUG_ASSERT(false);
1997  return 0.0;
1998  }
1999  longlong val_int(void) const final {
2000  DBUG_ASSERT(false);
2001  return 0;
2002  }
2003  my_decimal *val_decimal(my_decimal *) const final {
2004  DBUG_ASSERT(false);
2005  return nullptr;
2006  }
2007  String *val_str(String *, String *) const final {
2008  DBUG_ASSERT(false);
2009  return nullptr;
2010  }
2011  int cmp(const uchar *, const uchar *) const final {
2012  DBUG_ASSERT(false);
2013  return -1;
2014  }
2015  void sql_type(String &) const final { DBUG_ASSERT(false); }
2016  size_t make_sort_key(uchar *, size_t) const final {
2017  DBUG_ASSERT(false);
2018  return 0;
2019  }
2020  Field *clone(MEM_ROOT *mem_root) const final {
2021  return new (mem_root) Create_field_wrapper(*this);
2022  }
2023  /* purecov: end */
2024 };

2207 /* New decimal/numeric field which use fixed point arithmetic */
2208 class Field_new_decimal : public Field_num {
2209  private:
2210  /**
2211  Normally, the underlying decimal code will degrade values' excessive
2212  precision. E.g. value 0.0 stored as decimal(10,4) will be returned as
2213  decimal(4,4). This is fine for general purpose, but isn't usable for
2214  multi-valued index. Field_typed_array uses a field for conversion and it
2215  expects the value read from it to be exactly same as it would be stored
2216  in SE, i.e with preserved precision. Otherwise, SE won't be able to
2217  index it.
2218  TRUE here tells underlying DECIMAL reading code to keep the precision as
2219  is.
2220  */
2221  bool m_keep_precision{false};
2222  int do_save_field_metadata(uchar *first_byte) const final;
2223 
2224  public:
2225  /* The maximum number of decimal digits can be stored */
2226  uint precision;
2227  uint bin_size;
2228  /*
2229  Constructors take max_length of the field as a parameter - not the
2230  precision as the number of decimal digits allowed.
2231  So for example we need to count length from precision handling
2232  CREATE TABLE ( DECIMAL(x,y))
2233  */
2234  Field_new_decimal(uchar *ptr_arg, uint32 len_arg, uchar *null_ptr_arg,
2235  uchar null_bit_arg, uchar auto_flags_arg,
2236  const char *field_name_arg, uint8 dec_arg, bool zero_arg,
2237  bool unsigned_arg);
2238  Field_new_decimal(uint32 len_arg, bool is_nullable_arg,
2239  const char *field_name_arg, uint8 dec_arg,
2240  bool unsigned_arg);
2241  enum_field_types type() const final { return MYSQL_TYPE_NEWDECIMAL; }
2242  enum ha_base_keytype key_type() const final { return HA_KEYTYPE_BINARY; }
2243  Item_result result_type() const final { return DECIMAL_RESULT; }
2244  type_conversion_status reset() final;
2245  type_conversion_status store_value(const my_decimal *decimal_value);
2246  void set_value_on_overflow(my_decimal *decimal_value, bool sign) const;
2247  type_conversion_status store(const char *to, size_t length,
2248  const CHARSET_INFO *charset) final;
2249  type_conversion_status store(double nr) final;
2250  type_conversion_status store(longlong nr, bool unsigned_val) final;
2251  type_conversion_status store_time(MYSQL_TIME *ltime, uint8 dec) final;
2252  type_conversion_status store_decimal(const my_decimal *) final;
2253  double val_real() const final;
2254  longlong val_int() const final;
2255  my_decimal *val_decimal(my_decimal *) const final;
2256  bool get_date(MYSQL_TIME *ltime, my_time_flags_t fuzzydate) const final;
2257  bool get_time(MYSQL_TIME *ltime) const final;
2258  String *val_str(String *, String *) const final;
2259  int cmp(const uchar *, const uchar *) const final;
2260  size_t make_sort_key(uchar *buff, size_t length) const final;
2261  bool zero_pack() const final { return false; }
2262  void sql_type(String &str) const final;
2263  uint32 max_display_length() const final { return field_length; }
2264  uint32 pack_length() const final { return (uint32)bin_size; }
2265  uint pack_length_from_metadata(uint field_metadata) const final;
2266  bool compatible_field_size(uint field_metadata, Relay_log_info *, uint16,
2267  int *order_var) const final;
2268  uint is_equal(const Create_field *new_field) const final;
2269  Field_new_decimal *clone(MEM_ROOT *mem_root) const final {
2270  DBUG_ASSERT(type() == MYSQL_TYPE_NEWDECIMAL);
2271  return new (mem_root) Field_new_decimal(*this);
2272  }
2273  const uchar *unpack(uchar *to, const uchar *from, uint param_data) final;
2274  static Field *create_from_item(const Item *item);
2275  bool send_to_protocol(Protocol *protocol) const final;
2276  void set_keep_precision(bool arg) { m_keep_precision = arg; }
2277 };

2428  bool unsigned_arg)
2429  : Field_num(nullptr, len_arg,
2430  is_nullable_arg ? &dummy_null_buffer : nullptr, 0, NONE,
2431  field_name_arg, 0, false, unsigned_arg) {}

2434  enum ha_base_keytype key_type() const final {
2435  return is_unsigned() ? HA_KEYTYPE_ULONG_INT : HA_KEYTYPE_LONG_INT;
2436  }

2438  const CHARSET_INFO *charset) final;

2446  size_t make_sort_key(uchar *buff, size_t length) const final;
2447  uint32 pack_length() const final { return PACK_LENGTH; }
2448  void sql_type(String &str) const final;

2450  return MY_INT32_NUM_DECIMAL_DIGITS;
2451  }

2454  return new (mem_root) Field_long(*this);
2455  }

2457  return pack_int32(to, from, max_length);
2458  }

2460  uint param_data MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) final {
2461  return unpack_int32(to, from);
2462  }

2655 /*
2656  Abstract class for TIME, DATE, DATETIME, TIMESTAMP
2657  with and without fractional part.
2658 */
2659 class Field_temporal : public Field {
2660  protected:
2661  uint8 dec; // Number of fractional digits
2662 
2663  /**
2664  Adjust number of decimal digits from DECIMAL_NOT_SPECIFIED to
2665  DATETIME_MAX_DECIMALS
2666  */
2667  static uint8 normalize_dec(uint8 dec_arg) {
2668  return dec_arg == DECIMAL_NOT_SPECIFIED ? DATETIME_MAX_DECIMALS : dec_arg;
2669  }
2670 
2671  /**
2672  Low level routine to store a MYSQL_TIME value into a field.
2673  The value must be already properly rounded or truncated
2674  and checked for being a valid TIME/DATE/DATETIME value.
2675 
2676  @param[in] ltime MYSQL_TIME value.
2677  @param[out] error Error flag vector, set in case of error.
2678  @retval false In case of success.
2679  @retval true In case of error.
2680  */
2681  virtual type_conversion_status store_internal(const MYSQL_TIME *ltime,
2682  int *error) = 0;
2683 
2684  /**
2685  Low level routine to store a MYSQL_TIME value into a field
2686  with rounding/truncation according to the field decimals() value and
2687  sql_mode.
2688 
2689  @param[in] ltime MYSQL_TIME value.
2690  @param[out] warnings Error flag vector, set in case of error.
2691  @retval false In case of success.
2692  @retval true In case of error.
2693  */
2694  virtual type_conversion_status store_internal_adjust_frac(MYSQL_TIME *ltime,
2695  int *warnings) = 0;
2696 
2697  /**
2698  Store a temporal value in lldiv_t into a field,
2699  with rounding according to the field decimals() value.
2700 
2701  @param[in] lld Temporal value.
2702  @param[out] warning Warning flag vector.
2703  @retval false In case of success.
2704  @retval true In case of error.
2705  */
2706  type_conversion_status store_lldiv_t(const lldiv_t *lld, int *warning);
2707 
2708  /**
2709  Convert a string to MYSQL_TIME, according to the field type.
2710 
2711  @param[in] str String
2712  @param[in] len String length
2713  @param[in] cs String character set
2714  @param[out] ltime The value is stored here
2715  @param[out] status Conversion status
2716  @retval false Conversion went fine, ltime contains a valid time
2717  @retval true Conversion failed, ltime was reset and contains nothing
2718  */
2719  virtual bool convert_str_to_TIME(const char *str, size_t len,
2720  const CHARSET_INFO *cs, MYSQL_TIME *ltime,
2721  MYSQL_TIME_STATUS *status) = 0;
2722  /**
2723  Convert a number with fractional part with nanosecond precision
2724  into MYSQL_TIME, according to the field type. Nanoseconds
2725  are rounded to milliseconds and added to ltime->second_part.
2726 
2727  @param[in] nr Number
2728  @param[in] unsigned_val SIGNED/UNSIGNED flag
2729  @param[in] nanoseconds Fractional part in nanoseconds
2730  @param[out] ltime The value is stored here
2731  @param[in,out] warning Warnings found during execution
2732 
2733  @return Conversion status
2734  @retval false On success
2735  @retval true On error
2736  */
2737  virtual type_conversion_status convert_number_to_TIME(longlong nr,
2738  bool unsigned_val,
2739  int nanoseconds,
2740  MYSQL_TIME *ltime,
2741  int *warning) = 0;
2742 
2743  /**
2744  Convert an integer number into MYSQL_TIME, according to the field type.
2745 
2746  @param[in] nr Number
2747  @param[in] unsigned_val SIGNED/UNSIGNED flag
2748  @param[out] ltime The value is stored here
2749  @param[in,out] warnings Warnings found during execution
2750 
2751  @retval false On success
2752  @retval true On error
2753  */
2754  longlong convert_number_to_datetime(longlong nr, bool unsigned_val,
2755  MYSQL_TIME *ltime, int *warnings);
2756 
2757  /**
2758  Set warnings from a warning vector.
2759  Note, multiple warnings can be set at the same time.
2760  Every warning in the bit vector is set by an individual
2761  set_datetime_warning() call.
2762 
2763  @param str Value.
2764  @param warnings Warning vector.
2765 
2766  @retval false Function reported warning
2767  @retval true Function reported error
2768 
2769  @note STRICT mode can convert warnings to error.
2770  */
2771  bool set_warnings(const ErrConvString &str, int warnings)
2772  MY_ATTRIBUTE((warn_unused_result));
2773 
2774  /**
2775  Flags that are passed as "flag" argument to
2776  check_date(), number_to_datetime(), str_to_datetime().
2777 
2778  Flags depend on the session sql_mode settings, such as
2779  MODE_NO_ZERO_DATE, MODE_NO_ZERO_IN_DATE.
2780  Also, Field_newdate, Field_datetime, Field_datetimef add TIME_FUZZY_DATE
2781  to the session sql_mode settings, to allow relaxed date format,
2782  while Field_timestamp, Field_timestampf do not.
2783 
2784  @param thd THD
2785  @retval sql_mode flags mixed with the field type flags.
2786  */
2787  virtual my_time_flags_t date_flags(
2788  const THD *thd MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) const {
2789  return 0;
2790  }
2791 
2792  /**
2793  Flags that are passed as "flag" argument to
2794  check_date(), number_to_datetime(), str_to_datetime().
2795  Similar to the above when we don't have a THD value.
2796  */
2797  my_time_flags_t date_flags() const;
2798 
2799  /**
2800  Produce warning or note about double datetime data saved into field.
2801 
2802  @param level level of message (Note/Warning/Error)
2803  @param code error code of message to be produced
2804  @param val error parameter (the value)
2805  @param ts_type type of datetime value (datetime/date/time)
2806  @param truncate_increment whether we should increase truncated fields count
2807 
2808  @retval false Function reported warning
2809  @retval true Function reported error
2810 
2811  @note
2812  This function will always produce some warning but won't increase
2813  truncated fields counter if check_for_truncated_fields == FIELD_CHECK_IGNORE
2814  for current thread.
2815  */
2816  bool set_datetime_warning(Sql_condition::enum_severity_level level, uint code,
2817  const ErrConvString &val,
2818  enum_mysql_timestamp_type ts_type,
2819  int truncate_increment)
2820  MY_ATTRIBUTE((warn_unused_result));
2821 
2822  public:
2823  /**
2824  Constructor for Field_temporal
2825  @param ptr_arg See Field definition
2826  @param null_ptr_arg See Field definition
2827  @param null_bit_arg See Field definition
2828  @param auto_flags_arg See Field definition
2829  @param field_name_arg See Field definition
2830  @param len_arg Number of characters in the integer part.
2831  @param dec_arg Number of second fraction digits, 0..6.
2832  */
2833  Field_temporal(uchar *ptr_arg, uchar *null_ptr_arg, uchar null_bit_arg,
2834  uchar auto_flags_arg, const char *field_name_arg,
2835  uint32 len_arg, uint8 dec_arg)
2836  : Field(ptr_arg,
2837  len_arg +
2838  ((normalize_dec(dec_arg)) ? normalize_dec(dec_arg) + 1 : 0),
2839  null_ptr_arg, null_bit_arg, auto_flags_arg, field_name_arg) {
2840  set_flag(BINARY_FLAG);
2841  dec = normalize_dec(dec_arg);
2842  }
2843  Item_result result_type() const final { return STRING_RESULT; }
2844  uint32 max_display_length() const final { return field_length; }
2845  bool str_needs_quotes() const final { return true; }
2846  uint is_equal(const Create_field *new_field) const final;
2847  Item_result numeric_context_result_type() const final {
2848  return dec ? DECIMAL_RESULT : INT_RESULT;
2849  }
2850  enum Item_result cmp_type() const final { return INT_RESULT; }
2851  enum Derivation derivation() const final { return DERIVATION_NUMERIC; }
2852  uint repertoire() const final { return MY_REPERTOIRE_NUMERIC; }
2853  const CHARSET_INFO *charset() const final { return &my_charset_numeric; }
2854  bool can_be_compared_as_longlong() const final { return true; }
2855  bool binary() const final { return true; }
2856  type_conversion_status store(const char *str, size_t len,
2857  const CHARSET_INFO *cs) final;
2858  type_conversion_status store_decimal(const my_decimal *decimal) final;
2859  type_conversion_status store(longlong nr, bool unsigned_val) override;
2860  type_conversion_status store(double nr) final;
2861  double val_real() const override // FSP-enable types redefine it.
2862  {
2863  return (double)val_int();
2864  }
2865  my_decimal *val_decimal(
2866  my_decimal *decimal_value) const override; // FSP types redefine it
2867 };
2868 
2869 /**
2870  Abstract class for types with date
2871  with optional time, with or without fractional part:
2872  DATE, DATETIME, DATETIME(N), TIMESTAMP, TIMESTAMP(N).
2873 */
2874 class Field_temporal_with_date : public Field_temporal {
2875  protected:
2876  /**
2877  Low level function to get value into MYSQL_TIME,
2878  without checking for being valid.
2879  */
2880  virtual bool get_date_internal(MYSQL_TIME *ltime) const = 0;
2881 
2882  virtual bool get_date_internal_at_utc(MYSQL_TIME *ltime) const {
2883  return get_date_internal(ltime);
2884  }
2885 
2886  /**
2887  Get value into MYSQL_TIME and check TIME_NO_ZERO_DATE flag.
2888  @retval True on error: we get a zero value but flags disallow zero dates.
2889  @retval False on success.
2890  */
2891  bool get_internal_check_zero(MYSQL_TIME *ltime,
2892  my_time_flags_t fuzzydate) const;
2893 
2894  type_conversion_status convert_number_to_TIME(longlong nr, bool unsigned_val,
2895  int nanoseconds,
2896  MYSQL_TIME *ltime,
2897  int *warning) final;
2898  bool convert_str_to_TIME(const char *str, size_t len, const CHARSET_INFO *cs,
2899  MYSQL_TIME *ltime, MYSQL_TIME_STATUS *status) final;
2900 
2901  type_conversion_status store_internal_adjust_frac(MYSQL_TIME *ltime,
2902  int *warnings) final;
2903  using Field_temporal::date_flags;
2904 
2905  public:
2906  /**
2907  Constructor for Field_temporal
2908  @param ptr_arg See Field definition
2909  @param null_ptr_arg See Field definition
2910  @param null_bit_arg See Field definition
2911  @param auto_flags_arg See Field definition
2912  @param field_name_arg See Field definition
2913  @param int_length_arg Number of characters in the integer part.
2914  @param dec_arg Number of second fraction digits, 0..6.
2915  */
2916  Field_temporal_with_date(uchar *ptr_arg, uchar *null_ptr_arg,
2917  uchar null_bit_arg, uchar auto_flags_arg,
2918  const char *field_name_arg, uint8 int_length_arg,
2919  uint8 dec_arg)
2920  : Field_temporal(ptr_arg, null_ptr_arg, null_bit_arg, auto_flags_arg,
2921  field_name_arg, int_length_arg, dec_arg) {}
2922  bool send_to_protocol(Protocol *protocol) const override;
2923  type_conversion_status store_time(MYSQL_TIME *ltime, uint8 dec) final;
2924  String *val_str(String *, String *) const override;
2925  longlong val_time_temporal() const override;
2926  longlong val_date_temporal() const override;
2927  longlong val_time_temporal_at_utc() const override;
2928  longlong val_date_temporal_at_utc() const override;
2929  bool get_time(MYSQL_TIME *ltime) const final {
2930  return get_date(ltime, TIME_FUZZY_DATE);
2931  }
2932  /* Validate the value stored in a field */
2933  type_conversion_status validate_stored_val(THD *thd) override;
2934 };

2936 /**
2937  Abstract class for types with date and time,
2938  with or without fractional part:
2939  DATETIME, DATETIME(N), TIMESTAMP, TIMESTAMP(N).
2940 */
2941 class Field_temporal_with_date_and_time : public Field_temporal_with_date {
2942  private:
2943  int do_save_field_metadata(uchar *metadata_ptr) const override {
2944  if (decimals()) {
2945  *metadata_ptr = decimals();
2946  return 1;

3651 class Field_blob : public Field_longstr {
3652  virtual type_conversion_status store_internal(const char *from, size_t length,
3653  const CHARSET_INFO *cs);
3654  /**
3655  Copy value to memory storage.
3656  */
3657  type_conversion_status store_to_mem(const char *from, size_t length,
3658  const CHARSET_INFO *cs, size_t max_length,
3659  Blob_mem_storage *);
3660 
3661  protected:
3662  /**
3663  The number of bytes used to represent the length of the blob.
3664  */
3665  uint packlength;
3666 
3667  /**
3668  The 'value'-object is a cache fronting the storage engine.
3669  */
3670  String value;
3671 
3672  private:
3673  /**
3674  In order to support update of virtual generated columns of blob type,
3675  we need to allocate the space blob needs on server for old_row and
3676  new_row respectively. This variable is used to record the
3677  allocated blob space for old_row.
3678  */
3679  String old_value;
3680 
3681  /**
3682  Whether we need to move the content of 'value' to 'old_value' before
3683  updating the BLOB stored in 'value'. This needs to be done for
3684  updates of BLOB columns that are virtual since the storage engine
3685  does not have its own copy of the old 'value'. This variable is set
3686  to true when we read the data into 'value'. It is reset when we move
3687  'value' to 'old_value'. The purpose of having this is to avoid that we
3688  do the move operation from 'value' to 'old_value' more than one time per
3689  record.
3690  Currently, this variable is introduced because the following call in
3691  sql_data_change.cc:
3692  \/\**
3693  @todo combine this call to update_generated_write_fields() with the one
3694  in fill_record() to avoid updating virtual generated fields twice.
3695  *\/
3696  if (table->has_gcol())
3697  update_generated_write_fields(table->write_set, table);
3698  When the @todo is done, m_keep_old_value can be deleted.
3699  */
3700  bool m_keep_old_value;
3701 
3702  /**
3703  Backup String for table's blob fields.
3704  UPDATE of a virtual field (for index update) requires two values to be
3705  kept at the same time - 'new' and 'old' since SE (InnoDB) doesn't know the
3706  latter. In the case when there was an indexed record, it got deleted and
3707  When INSERT inserts into an index a record that coincides with a
3708  previously deleted one, InnoDB needs to recalculate value that was
3709  deleted in order to properly insert the new one.
3710  When two above overlap, a field have to keep 3 different values at the
3711  same time - 'new', 'old' and 'deleted'.
3712  This backup_value is used by @see my_eval_gcolumn_expr_helper() to save
3713  'new' and provide space for 'deleted' to avoid thrashing the former.
3714  Unlike the old_value, backup_value is allocated once and reused for each
3715  new re-calculation, to avoid excessive [re-]allocations. It's freed at the
3716  end of statement. Since InnoDB consumes calculated values only after all
3717  needed table's virtual fields were calculated, we have to have such backup
3718  buffer for each field.
3719  */
3720  String m_blob_backup;
3721 
3722 #ifndef DBUG_OFF
3723  /**
3724  Whether the field uses table's backup value storage. @see
3725  TABLE::m_blob_backup. Used only for debug.
3726  */
3727  bool m_uses_backup{false};
3728 #endif
3729 
3730  protected:
3731  /**
3732  Store ptr and length.
3733  */
3734  void store_ptr_and_length(const char *from, uint32 length) {
3735  store_length(length);
3736  memmove(ptr + packlength, &from, sizeof(char *));
3737  }
3738 
3739  public:
3740  Field_blob(uchar *ptr_arg, uchar *null_ptr_arg, uchar null_bit_arg,
3741  uchar auto_flags_arg, const char *field_name_arg,
3742  TABLE_SHARE *share, uint blob_pack_length, const CHARSET_INFO *cs);
3743 
3744  Field_blob(uint32 len_arg, bool is_nullable_arg, const char *field_name_arg,
3745  const CHARSET_INFO *cs, bool set_packlength)
3746  : Field_longstr(nullptr, len_arg,
3747  is_nullable_arg ? &dummy_null_buffer : nullptr, 0, NONE,
3748  field_name_arg, cs),
3749  packlength(4),
3750  m_keep_old_value(false) {
3751  set_flag(BLOB_FLAG);
3752  if (set_packlength) {
3753  packlength = len_arg <= 255
3754  ? 1
3755  : len_arg <= 65535 ? 2 : len_arg <= 16777215 ? 3 : 4;
3756  }
3757  }
3758 
3759  /// Copy static information and reset dynamic information.
3760  Field_blob(const Field_blob &field)
3761  : Field_longstr(field),
3762  packlength(field.packlength),
3763  value(),
3764  old_value(),
3765  m_keep_old_value(field.m_keep_old_value),
3766  m_blob_backup() {
3767 #ifndef DBUG_OFF
3768  m_uses_backup = field.m_uses_backup;
3769 #endif
3770  }
3771 
3772  explicit Field_blob(uint32 packlength_arg);
3773

3775  enum_field_types type() const override { return MYSQL_TYPE_BLOB; }
3776  bool match_collation_to_optimize_range() const override { return true; }
3777  enum ha_base_keytype key_type() const override {
3778  return binary() ? HA_KEYTYPE_VARBINARY2 : HA_KEYTYPE_VARTEXT2;
3779  }
3780  type_conversion_status store(const char *to, size_t length,
3781  const CHARSET_INFO *charset) override;
3782  type_conversion_status store(double nr) override;
3783  type_conversion_status store(longlong nr, bool unsigned_val) override;
3784  type_conversion_status store(const Field *from);
3785  double val_real() const override;
3786  longlong val_int() const override;
3787  String *val_str(String *, String *) const override;
3788  my_decimal *val_decimal(my_decimal *) const override;
3789  int cmp_max(const uchar *, const uchar *, uint max_length) const final;
3790  int cmp(const uchar *a, const uchar *b) const final {
3791  return cmp_max(a, b, ~0L);
3792  }
3793  int cmp(const uchar *a, uint32 a_length, const uchar *b,
3794  uint32 b_length) const; // No override.
3795  int cmp_binary(const uchar *a, const uchar *b,
3796  uint32 max_length = ~0L) const override;
3797  int key_cmp(const uchar *, const uchar *) const override;
3798  int key_cmp(const uchar *str, uint length) const override;
3799  uint32 key_length() const override { return 0; }
3800  size_t make_sort_key(uchar *buff, size_t length) const override;
3801  uint32 pack_length() const final {
3802  return (uint32)(packlength + portable_sizeof_char_ptr);
3803  }
3804 
3805  /**
3806  Return the packed length without the pointer size added.
3807 
3808  This is used to determine the size of the actual data in the row
3809  buffer.
3810 
3811  @returns The length of the raw data itself without the pointer.
3812  */
3813  uint32 pack_length_no_ptr() const { return (uint32)(packlength); }
3814  uint row_pack_length() const final { return pack_length_no_ptr(); }
3815  uint32 max_data_length() const final {
3816  return (uint32)(((ulonglong)1 << (packlength * 8)) - 1);
3817  }
3818  size_t get_field_buffer_size() { return value.alloced_length(); }
3819  void store_length(uchar *i_ptr, uint i_packlength, uint32 i_number);
3820  inline void store_length(uint32 number) {
3821  store_length(ptr, packlength, number);
3822  }
3823  uint32 data_length(ptrdiff_t row_offset = 0) const final {
3824  return get_length(row_offset);
3825  }
3826  uint32 get_length(ptrdiff_t row_offset = 0) const;
3827  uint32 get_length(const uchar *ptr, uint packlength) const;
3828  uint32 get_length(const uchar *ptr_arg) const;
3829  /** Get a const pointer to the BLOB data of this field. */
3830  const uchar *get_blob_data() const { return get_blob_data(ptr + packlength); }
3831  /** Get a non-const pointer to the BLOB data of this field. */
3832  uchar *get_blob_data(ptrdiff_t row_offset = 0) {
3833  // row_offset is only used by NDB
3834  return get_blob_data(ptr + packlength + row_offset);
3835  }
3836  /** Get a const pointer to the BLOB data of this field. */
3837  const uchar *data_ptr() const final { return get_blob_data(); }
3838 
3839  protected:
3840  /**
3841  Get the BLOB data pointer stored at the specified position in the record
3842  buffer.
3843  */
3844  static uchar *get_blob_data(const uchar *position) {
3845  uchar *data;
3846  memcpy(&data, position, sizeof(data));
3847  return data;
3848  }
3849 
3850  public:
3851  void set_ptr(const uchar *length, const uchar *data) {
3852  memcpy(ptr, length, packlength);
3853  memcpy(ptr + packlength, &data, sizeof(char *));
3854  }
3855  void set_ptr_offset(ptrdiff_t ptr_diff, uint32 length, const uchar *data) {
3856  uchar *ptr_ofs = ptr + ptr_diff;
3857  store_length(ptr_ofs, packlength, length);
3858  memcpy(ptr_ofs + packlength, &data, sizeof(char *));
3859  }
3860  void set_ptr(uint32 length, const uchar *data) {
3861  set_ptr_offset(0, length, data);
3862  }
3863  size_t get_key_image(uchar *buff, size_t length,
3864  imagetype type) const override;
3865  void set_key_image(const uchar *buff, size_t length) final;
3866  void sql_type(String &str) const override;
3867  bool copy();
3868  Field_blob *clone(MEM_ROOT *mem_root) const override {
3869  DBUG_ASSERT(type() == MYSQL_TYPE_BLOB);
3870  return new (mem_root) Field_blob(*this);
3871  }
3872  uchar *pack(uchar *to, const uchar *from, size_t max_length) const final;
3873  uchar *pack_with_metadata_bytes(uchar *to, const uchar *from,
3874  uint max_length) const final;
3875  const uchar *unpack(uchar *, const uchar *from, uint param_data) final;
3876  uint max_packed_col_length() const final;
3877  void mem_free() final {
3878  // Free all allocated space
3879  value.mem_free();
3880  old_value.mem_free();
3881  m_blob_backup.mem_free();
3882  }
3883  bool has_charset() const override {
3884  return charset() == &my_charset_bin ? false : true;
3885  }
3886  uint32 max_display_length() const final;
3887  uint32 char_length() const override;
3888  bool copy_blob_value(MEM_ROOT *mem_root);
3889  uint is_equal(const Create_field *new_field) const override;
3890  bool is_text_key_type() const final { return binary() ? false : true; }
3891 
3892  /**
3893  Mark that the BLOB stored in value should be copied before updating it.
3894 
3895  When updating virtual generated columns we need to keep the old
3896  'value' for BLOBs since this can be needed when the storage engine
3897  does the update. During read of the record the old 'value' for the
3898  BLOB is evaluated and stored in 'value'. This function is to be used
3899  to specify that we need to copy this BLOB 'value' into 'old_value'
3900  before we compute the new BLOB 'value'. For more information @see
3901  Field_blob::keep_old_value().
3902  */
3903  void set_keep_old_value(bool old_value_flag) {
3904  /*
3905  We should only need to keep a copy of the blob 'value' in the case
3906  where this is a virtual genarated column (that is indexed).
3907  */
3908  DBUG_ASSERT(is_virtual_gcol());
3909 
3910  /*
3911  If set to true, ensure that 'value' is copied to 'old_value' when
3912  keep_old_value() is called.
3913  */
3914  m_keep_old_value = old_value_flag;
3915  }
3916 
3917  /**
3918  Save the current BLOB value to avoid that it gets overwritten.
3919 
3920  This is used when updating virtual generated columns that are
3921  BLOBs. Some storage engines require that we have both the old and
3922  new BLOB value for virtual generated columns that are indexed in
3923  order for the storage engine to be able to maintain the index. This
3924  function will transfer the buffer storing the current BLOB value
3925  from 'value' to 'old_value'. This avoids that the current BLOB value
3926  is over-written when the new BLOB value is saved into this field.
3927 
3928  The reason this requires special handling when updating/deleting
3929  virtual columns of BLOB type is that the BLOB value is not known to
3930  the storage engine. For stored columns, the "old" BLOB value is read
3931  by the storage engine, Field_blob is made to point to the engine's
3932  internal buffer; Field_blob's internal buffer (Field_blob::value)
3933  isn't used and remains available to store the "new" value. For
3934  virtual generated columns, the "old" value is written directly into
3935  Field_blob::value when reading the record to be
3936  updated/deleted. This is done in update_generated_read_fields().
3937  Since, in this case, the "old" value already occupies the place to
3938  store the "new" value, we must call this function before we write
3939  the "new" value into Field_blob::value object so that the "old"
3940  value does not get over-written. The table->record[1] buffer will
3941  have a pointer that points to the memory buffer inside
3942  old_value. The storage engine will use table->record[1] to read the
3943  old value for the BLOB and use table->record[0] to read the new
3944  value.
3945 
3946  This function must be called before we store the new BLOB value in
3947  this field object.
3948  */
3949  void keep_old_value() {
3950  /*
3951  We should only need to keep a copy of the blob value in the case
3952  where this is a virtual genarated column (that is indexed).
3953  */
3954  DBUG_ASSERT(is_virtual_gcol());
3955 
3956  // Transfer ownership of the current BLOB value to old_value
3957  if (m_keep_old_value) {
3958  old_value.takeover(value);
3959  m_keep_old_value = false;
3960  }
3961  }
3962 
3963  /**
3964  Use to store the blob value into an allocated space.
3965  */
3966  void store_in_allocated_space(const char *from, uint32 length) {
3967  store_ptr_and_length(from, length);
3968  }
3969 
3970  /**
3971  Backup data stored in 'value' into the backup_value
3972  @see Field_blob::backup_value
3973 
3974  @returns
3975  true if backup fails
3976  false otherwise
3977  */
3978  bool backup_blob_field();
3979 
3980  /**
3981  Restore backup value
3982  @see Field_blob::backup_value
3983  */
3984  void restore_blob_backup();
3985 
3986  private:
3987  int do_save_field_metadata(uchar *first_byte) const override;
3988 };

4207 /**
4208  Field that stores array of values of the same type.
4209 
4210  This Field class is used together with Item_func_array_cast class
4211  (CAST( .. AS .. ARRAY) function) in implementation of multi-valued index.
4212  Effectively it's a JSON field that contains a single JSON array. When a
4213  JSON value is stored, it's checked to be either a scalar, or an array.
4214  All source values are converted using the internal conversion field and
4215  stored as an array. Field_typed_array ensures that all values stored
4216  in the array have the same type and precision - the one specified by user.
4217  This way InnoDB doesn't have to do the conversion on its own and can easily
4218  index them.
4219 
4220  The Field_typed_array always reports type of its element and from this
4221  point of view it's undistinguishable from regular field having the same
4222  type. Due to that, fields are differentiated by is_array() property.
4223  Field_typed_array returns true, all other fields - false.
4224 
4225  For conversion and index applicability tests, Field_typed_array employs a
4226  conversion field, which is a regular Field class of array's element type.
4227  It's stored in the m_conv_field. All Field_typed_array::store_*() methods
4228  store values to the conversion field. Conversion field and typed array
4229  field are sharing same field_index, to allow correct read/write_set
4230  checks. So the field always have to be marked for read in order to allow
4231  read of conversions' results.
4232 
4233  @see Item_func_array_cast
4234 */
4235 
4236 class Field_typed_array final : public Field_json {
4237  /// Conversion item_field
4238  Item_field *m_conv_item{nullptr};
4239  /// The array element's real type.
4240  enum_field_types m_elt_type;
4241  /// Element's decimals
4242  uint m_elt_decimals;
4243  /// Element's charset
4244  const CHARSET_INFO *m_elt_charset;
4245  const bool unsigned_flag;
4246 
4247  public:
4248  /**
4249  Constructs a Field_typed_array that is a copy of another Field_typed_array.
4250  @param other the other Field_typed_array object
4251  */
4252  Field_typed_array(const Field_typed_array &other);
4253  /**
4254  Constructs a Field_typed_array object.
4255  */
4256  Field_typed_array(enum_field_types elt_type, bool elt_is_unsigned,
4257  size_t elt_length, uint elt_decimals, uchar *ptr_arg,
4258  uchar *null_ptr_arg, uint null_bit_arg,
4259  uchar auto_flags_arg, const char *field_name_arg,
4260  TABLE_SHARE *share, uint blob_pack_length,

4299  uchar *, uint) const override;
4300  /**

4302  end_range during range access. Since there's no order defined for sorting
4303  set of arrays, always return -1 here, allowing all records fetched from
4304  SE to be returned to server. They will be filtered by WHERE condition later.
4305  */
4306  int key_cmp(const uchar *, const uchar *) const override { return -1; }

4310  condition check, and the latter always use binary collation, so no point

4346  const char *get_index_name() const;

4368  /**
4369  Save the field metadata for typed array fields.
4370 
4371  Saved metadata contains element type (1 byte) and up to 3 bytes of

4491 
4492 /*
4493  Note:
4494  To use Field_bit::cmp_binary() you need to copy the bits stored in
4495  the beginning of the record (the NULL bytes) to each memory you
4496  want to compare (where the arguments point).
4497 
4498  This is the reason:
4499  - Field_bit::cmp_binary() is only implemented in the base class
4500  (Field::cmp_binary()).
4501  - Field::cmp_binary() currenly use pack_length() to calculate how
4502  long the data is.
4503  - pack_length() includes size of the bits stored in the NULL bytes
4504  of the record.
4505 */
4506 class Field_bit : public Field {
4507  public:
4508  uchar *bit_ptr; // position in record where 'uneven' bits store
4509  uchar bit_ofs; // offset to 'uneven' high bits
4510  uint bit_len; // number of 'uneven' high bits
4511  uint bytes_in_rec;
4512  Field_bit(uchar *ptr_arg, uint32 len_arg, uchar *null_ptr_arg,
4513  uchar null_bit_arg, uchar *bit_ptr_arg, uchar bit_ofs_arg,
4514  uchar auto_flags_arg, const char *field_name_arg);
4515  enum_field_types type() const final { return MYSQL_TYPE_BIT; }
4516  enum ha_base_keytype key_type() const override { return HA_KEYTYPE_BIT; }
4517  uint32 max_display_length() const final { return field_length; }
4518  Item_result result_type() const final { return INT_RESULT; }
4519  type_conversion_status reset() final;
4520  type_conversion_status store(const char *to, size_t length,
4521  const CHARSET_INFO *charset) override;
4522  type_conversion_status store(double nr) final;
4523  type_conversion_status store(longlong nr, bool unsigned_val) final;
4524  type_conversion_status store_decimal(const my_decimal *) final;
4525  double val_real() const final;
4526  longlong val_int() const final;
4527  String *val_str(String *, String *) const final;
4528  bool str_needs_quotes() const final { return true; }
4529  my_decimal *val_decimal(my_decimal *) const final;
4530  int cmp(const uchar *a, const uchar *b) const final {
4531  DBUG_ASSERT(ptr == a || ptr == b);
4532  const uint cmp_len = bytes_in_rec + (bit_len != 0 ? 1 : 0);
4533  if (ptr == a)
4534  return Field_bit::key_cmp(b, cmp_len);
4535  else
4536  return -Field_bit::key_cmp(a, cmp_len);
4537  }
4538  int cmp_binary_offset(ptrdiff_t row_offset) const final {
4539  return cmp_offset(row_offset);
4540  }
4541  int cmp_max(const uchar *a, const uchar *b, uint max_length) const final;
4542  int key_cmp(const uchar *a, const uchar *b) const final {
4543  return cmp_binary(a, b);
4544  }
4545  int key_cmp(const uchar *str, uint length) const final;
4546  int cmp_offset(ptrdiff_t row_offset) const final;
4547  void get_image(uchar *buff, size_t length, const CHARSET_INFO *) const final {
4548  get_key_image(buff, length, itRAW);
4549  }
4550  void set_image(const uchar *buff, size_t length,
4551  const CHARSET_INFO *cs) final {
4552  Field_bit::store(pointer_cast<const char *>(buff), length, cs);
4553  }
4554  size_t get_key_image(uchar *buff, size_t length, imagetype type) const final;
4555  void set_key_image(const uchar *buff, size_t length) final {
4556  Field_bit::store(pointer_cast<const char *>(buff), length, &my_charset_bin);
4557  }
4558  size_t make_sort_key(uchar *buff, size_t length) const final {
4559  get_key_image(buff, length, itRAW);
4560  return length;
4561  }
4562  uint32 pack_length() const final { return (uint32)(field_length + 7) / 8; }
4563  uint32 pack_length_in_rec() const final { return bytes_in_rec; }
4564  uint pack_length_from_metadata(uint field_metadata) const final;
4565  uint row_pack_length() const final {
4566  return (bytes_in_rec + ((bit_len > 0) ? 1 : 0));
4567  }
4568  bool compatible_field_size(uint metadata, Relay_log_info *, uint16 mflags,
4569  int *order_var) const final;
4570  void sql_type(String &str) const override;
4571  uchar *pack(uchar *to, const uchar *from, size_t max_length) const final;
4572  const uchar *unpack(uchar *to, const uchar *from, uint param_data) final;
4573  void set_default() final;
4574 
4575  Field *new_key_field(MEM_ROOT *root, TABLE *new_table, uchar *new_ptr,
4576  uchar *new_null_ptr, uint new_null_bit) const final;
4577  void set_bit_ptr(uchar *bit_ptr_arg, uchar bit_ofs_arg) {
4578  bit_ptr = bit_ptr_arg;
4579  bit_ofs = bit_ofs_arg;
4580  }
4581  bool eq(const Field *field) const final {
4582  return (Field::eq(field) &&
4583  bit_ptr == down_cast<const Field_bit *>(field)->bit_ptr &&
4584  bit_ofs == down_cast<const Field_bit *>(field)->bit_ofs);
4585  }
4586  uint is_equal(const Create_field *new_field) const final;
4587  void move_field_offset(ptrdiff_t ptr_diff) final {
4588  Field::move_field_offset(ptr_diff);
4589  if (bit_ptr != nullptr) bit_ptr += ptr_diff;
4590  }
4591  void hash(ulong *nr, ulong *nr2) const final;
4592  Field_bit *clone(MEM_ROOT *mem_root) const override {
4593  DBUG_ASSERT(type() == MYSQL_TYPE_BIT);
4594  return new (mem_root) Field_bit(*this);
4595  }
4596 
4597  private:
4598  int do_save_field_metadata(uchar *first_byte) const final;
4599 };
